desc: MSI2 encodes the RNA-binding protein Musashi-2, which displays more than 90% homology withMusashi-1 protein at the amino acid level in the RNA-binding domain. Musashi2, like Musashi1, possesses m-Numb mRNA translation repressing activity, and thus activates Notch signaling to maintain self-renewal activity of neural stem cells (PMID: 15925591). In addition, Musashi-2 expression is required for self-renewal and pluripotency of embryonic stem cells in early stages of differentiation (PMID: 22496868). MSI2 is highly expressed in hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) of primitive origin, namely long-term (LT) HSCs, short-term (ST) HSCs and lymphoid myeloid primed progenitors (LMPP), and is important in regulating the stem cell compartment and proliferation of primitive progenitors downstream of LT-HSCs (PMID: 21613258). Overexpression of MSI2 in mouse models cooperates with the BCR-ABL1 oncoprotein to drive aggressive leukemia. MSI2 is over-expressed in human myeloid leukemias, and its expression level directly correlates with survival of patients with the disease (PMID: 20616797, 20639863).

articles.title: Musashi2 is required for the self-renewal and pluripotency of embryonic stem cells.
articles.reference: Wuebben EL et al. PloS one. 2012;7(4)e34827.

articles.title: Regulation of myeloid leukaemia by the cell-fate determinant Musashi.

articles.title: Musashi-2 regulates normal hematopoiesis and promotes aggressive myeloid leukemia.
articles.reference: Kharas MG et al. Nature medicine. 2010 Aug;16(8)903-8.

articles.title: Function of RNA-binding protein Musashi-1 in stem cells.

articles.title: Musashi 2 is a regulator of the HSC compartment identified by a retroviral insertion screen and knockout mice.
articles.reference: de Andrés-Aguayo L et al. Blood. 2011 Jul 21;118(3)554-64.

desc: MSI2, an RNA-binding protein expressed in stem cells of neural and hematopoietic origin, is over-expressed in myeloid leukemias.
